thinking.disposable_income: Pullman has a median income of $54,755, with 45.8% households earning less than $50,000. The community has limited disposable income, making them sensitive to cost increases in transportation and sales tax
thinking.discretionary_consumption: Given the income distribution and average household size of 2.1, discretionary spending is moderate to low. About 22.7% of households earn less than $25,000, suggesting many residents would be significantly impacted by increased costs
thinking.accessibility: 64% drive alone and 17.6% use transit for commuting. 16.1% have no vehicle, while 49.8% have one vehicle. The community needs balanced policies that maintain both driving and transit accessibility
thinking.decision_rationale: 1. Prioritize proposals with lower sales tax (0.5%) to protect discretionary spending. 2. Moderate transit fares ($1.25) to maintain affordability while supporting service quality. 3. Consider modest driving fees ($0.50) to improve transit without overly burdening drivers. 4. Balance travel time improvements with cost impacts. 5. Account for significant transit-dependent population (16.1% no vehicle)
